Definition: It is expected that you will classify the comments into two classes: an attack on identity and an attack on unidentity. an attack on identity relates to something brutal or unfair about a person, including appearance, race, gender and sexual orientation.

Comment: It was about 27 years ago.  Someone left a book ‘The Apparitions of Our Lady at Medjugorje’ by Svetoza Kraljevic O.F.M. on my desk at work. I read it and believed it to be a true story.  I thought if my mother comes to town I would surely go visit her. 
I told my husband about it. The next day he came home said I should go because someone left flyer about a trip to Medjugorje in his car.  At that time no one knew or talked about Medjugorje in a small town where we lived.
My friend and prayer partner asked me to stop at her house to pray on the way to the airport.  She thought it will bring blessings to her home.  We stopped by her house and I went to her prayer room while my husband was waiting in his truck.
As soon as I sat and closed my eyes to pray, I saw Holy Mary and so many angels that I could not count on the door way blessing and welcoming me despite my closed eyes. 
I then understood what it meant ‘multitude of angels’ in the bible.

Comment: First off, it is vital that everyone know that business taxes hit consumers, i.e. us.  Business will always raise prices to maintain their expected profit margin (or they will go out of business).  Some like to fool us and say that business tax does not hit the people.  This is a lie.

Moreover, the idea that investors pay taxes on money they don't actually get is crazy.  Investors in many companies never get dividends and a capital gain return is only received when stock involved is sold.  With the stock market fluctuations, one never knows whether one will achieve a capital gain (i.e. make money) or loss (i.e. lose money) when stock is sold.  Presently, investors pay tax when the deal is done, i.e. they know how much they have made.  Dividends if any are already taxed when they are received. Comment: I'm disappointed, I take the bus everyday from Fairview (next to the Senior Center) to the University, and my route has been axed. With the new system, it looks as though I would have to take 2, possibly 3, buses, plus additional walking time...in short, it will most likely be as quick or quicker to walk to school. I'm a bit surprised that there appears to be only one route going to the University now - if any young people were going to use the bus system, it would be students. I have never had an issue with the frequency of the buses - the 13 route is once an hour (I think an extra one comes around between 8 and 9am). I don't really see how this system is better if it potentially involves more walking, especially in a cold-climate city like Anchorage. I also just think that more walking would discourage people in general. Ideally, it would encourage people to get out and exercise, realistically, it will discourage people form taking the bus, possibly killing the system altogether.

Comment: "The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, popularized the idea of “paradigm shift” in science, the way perception of the physical universe can be turned upside down by abrupt changes in world view...."  I know Dr. Kingwell is far better informed than I about philosophy, but I'm not sure he's doing Thomas Kuhn's book justice here, which I read more than once when I was younger and which actually to some extent informs my own world view. 

 Kuhn said that paradigms shift when, after a long period of time anomalies pile up about things that are considered fact (the earth is flat, or the center of the solary system, etc.).   Finally so many anomalies accumulate, that the paradigm shifts.  The shift is not actually abrupt, but can appear so.  

This kind of thing applies to social affairs and politics as well.  Revolutions when they break out may same sudden and shocking, but the build up may have been going on for a long long time.  Suddenly the world becomes  a secular place.  And so on.

Comment: When she was a scrawny 11-year-old, Sherry Johnson found out one day that she was about to be married to a 20-year-old member of her church who had raped her.

“It was forced on me,” she recalls. She had become pregnant, she says, and child welfare authorities were investigating — so her family and church officials decided the simplest way to avoid a messy criminal case was to organize a wedding.

“My mom asked me if I wanted to get married, and I said, ‘I don’t know, what is marriage, how do I act like a wife?’” Johnson remembers today, many years later. “She said, ‘Well, I guess you’re just going to get married.’”

So she was. A government clerk in Tampa, Fla., refused to marry an 11-year-old, even though this was legal in the state, so the wedding party went to nearby Pinellas County, where the clerk issued a marriage license. The license (which I’ve examined) lists her birth date, so officials were aware of her age.

Comment: In the marine safety world, what a vessel should have aboard, especially for a voyage like this, is an EPIRB - Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon - that sends one's coordinates to SAR resources upon being manually or automatically (hydrostatic release) activated, and is registered to the ship so they know exactly what they're looking for and where.

Satellite phone is a nice extra, as is a SPOT device that even most non-mariners are aware of.

That they missed acquiring such basic survival gear makes you wonder what kind of "veteran sailors" they consulted before casting off.

The headline for this story should read "Idiots lucky to be alive; lost at sea 5 months for no good reason"

Comment: Measure 97's nonsensical drafting makes it probably the most unfair and regressive taxes considered in Oregon for many years. It raises taxes by 500 percent over what all corporations paid in Oregon income taxes last year, then targets a small number of corporation to pay the whole thing. It takes the entire profits of many retailers such as grocers, auto dealers, and big retailers like Costco, Fred Meyer, and Walmart, and Walgreens, forcing them to raise prices on consumer essentials like groceries and medicine.

The non-partisan Legislative Revenue Office estimates middle income Oregonians will pay $600 - $800 more per year in increased prices, with no exemptions for essentials. This is regressive taxation at its worst.

Comment: Thanks for your response :)

There is the ideal: No illegal immigration. A system that treats people who come here legally fairly. There is reality: 11 million undocumented immigrants.

You can't simply switch from reality to the ideal. For the places that have tried this (Arizona and Alabama) it resulted in very dire consequences for U.S. citizens, the economy, public safety, and the U.S. Constitution.  I'm for finding a compromise that that won't result in something ultimately hurting us and implementing policies the majority of people will regret - likely without solving the issue we want to solve. 

I think a combination of immigration reform, border security (not sure a wall is the answer, but I suppose it's a powerful symbol), continuing to deport criminals, and offering a path to citizenship or fair work visas for those already here is a reasonable compromise on all levels. People should have to make amends, but in thoughtful way that fixes it.

Comment: Another point on UBI, which I haven't seen discussed here, is to what extent does it actually discourage people from working? Consider this logic - if you're arguing that people should work, and that a UBI would make them lazy, I think it safe to assume you work, and do not consider yourself to be lazy. If you had a guaranteed income of a modest amount, would you just kick back and be a slob? I think it more likely that you would keep working, but enjoy greater leverage to secure good working conditions for yourself. You'd also probably spend more time with your family, and maybe have more time to pursue creative ventures of your own. 

Surely there's a balanced approach that finds a sufficient amount that guarantees a basic level of security and comfort while preserving the vibrant spirit of capitalism we all know and love.

Comment: Nate, you are right, they are surprisingly small compared to military planes today.   Yet still awesome.  We were able to tour  a B-17 and other WWII planes when they were here some months ago.  For a kid who grew up during WWII as I did, just being up close to that Flying Fortress gave me goose bumps; watching it land made me think of  tattered, damaged bombers returning from a raid over Europe, barely making to a British airfield with an engine missing and wounded crew aboard.
And  they are so small inside, yet had a crew of 10  crammed in there, pity the poor guy rolled up in the ball turret--all of this in a windy non-heated, non-pressured thin-shelled cylinder at 40 degrees below zero at 25,000 feet.  And even with all those guns, the "Fortress" suffered heavy casualties over Europe unless protected by long-range fighters.
Hard for folks today to understand what America  was like when we were fighting for survival and most everyone felt involved.
They were our Greatest Generation.

Comment: New York Times April 2015
Beyond mines in Kazakhstan that are among the most lucrative in the world, the sale gave the Russians control of one-fifth of all uranium production capacity in the United States. Since uranium is considered a strategic asset, with implications for national security, the deal had to be approved by a committee composed of representatives from a number of United States government agencies. Among the agencies that eventually signed off was the State Department, then headed by Mr. Clinton’s wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

As the Russians gradually assumed control of Uranium One in three separate transactions from 2009 to 2013, Canadian records show, a flow of cash made its way to the Clinton Foundation. Uranium One’s chairman used his family foundation to make four donations totaling $2.35 million. Those contributions were not publicly disclosed by the Clintons, despite an agreement Mrs. Clinton had struck with the Obama White House to publicly identify all donors.

We know who they are.  Since the inception of NATO in 1949, exactly one member nation has invoked Article 5 (collective defense of member nations): the United States, following the attacks of September 11, 2001. The United States, as much as any other member nation, depends in NATO for its own security. I guess it's hard to blame you for not knowing the facts or the recent history; neither does Trump.

Comment: Just incase you're curious about Breitbart's history: they used to post much more inflammatory articles. Now, they have pivoted to publishing less dramatic material (they'll often just repost an AP story that they think their readers can get worked up about), but they rely on their comments section to do the work. I challenge you to scroll through a comments section in Breitbart and not find someone professing that we should commit genocide against blacks or Muslims, or else threatening politicians and journalists with rape and murder. Breitbart doesn't *need* to write awful stuff anymore, in order to be America's leading site for the radicalization of white nationalist terrorists. I will continue to work assiduously to shut it down.

Comment: Fishing vessels sometimes need help.  And there are times when many of us need Coast Guard, or police, or fire protection, but two major distinctions between the situations must be considered: (1) we pay taxes to support those institutions and the cruise lines don't.  They purposefully register ships in foreign ports so they can avoid paying US income taxes on the vast majority of their income.  Carnival, the world's largest line (~50% of the market,) has been paying at a 1-1.5% tax rate for years, even though the corporate headquarters is in Miami for decades.  (2) Size matters. Dealing with the aftermath of a problem with a cruise ship crossing the Arctic will cost a fortune and they won't be canceling this trip because they know a storm is coming.  If the weather turns sour, a fishing vessel usually heads back to port.  I'm not saying they shouldn't go, but they should pay into some kind of insurance that will cover the cost of a serious problem.

Comment: The matter of Rail begins with discerning when to look at the forest and when to instead look at the trees.  Initially, A project begins at the forest view and future vision.  So, the burdens fall upon the affirmative actor, i.e. the project proposers.  A future vision does not meet such a burden.  So, the tree view next becomes pertinent, i.e. the detailed elements comprising of a competent financial and business plan.  The analytical shortfall of many is in using the wholistic "forest" perspective when the myopic "tree" perspective should instead be used, and vice-versa.  When that happens, nobody can respond to the circuitous analyses.

Comment: Ever hear of a breeder reactor? Combined with seawater uranium extraction, we could power the earth for 5 billion years at 1983 usage levels. That rivals the sun for longevity as a power source. Guess what the solution for fresh water decline is? More power for desalinization. Literally whatever the problem, more power is the answer. Overfishing is a problem. Aquaponics is a solution, but that requires power to circulate and in some cases cool the water. We get fish for protein and vegetables for carbs, fiber and vitamins, all from a highly efficient closed system. You can do this at home, but it will be done more efficiently at large scale. The power is available to do all we need for as long as we need, but simply comes at a cost greater than the fossil fuel still abundantly available, which is partly why we continue to use it. When that finally runs out, the will to survive will overcome the political barriers and we will move to nuclear, rather than die by the billions.

I wish them luck. Competition is good for the industry.

Comment: I recently read an analysis published by a legal journal which was written by a lawyer. He disagreed with the arguments used to challenge Khadr's right to obtain compensation for his travails but he was equally clear that it's entirely fair to argue that the matter should have been resolved in the courts rather than by settlement. The settlement does absolutely nothing to clarify or enhance the Charter rights of Canadians. It generates no case law or legal precedents upon which others can rely when their rights have been violated. And as for the economic argument (i.e. 'it was cheaper to settle'), there is often a cost to be paid to pursue justice. Interestingly, Lib politicians fought the extension of Charter rights to LGBTQ persons all the way to the Supreme Court on more than one occasion (and lost), at great expense to all concerned. The Libs are no Charter lovers and don't mind spending tax dollars in the cause of limiting the rights of some Canadians.

Comment: I don't think there's much anymore. I remember decades ago some products used the 60hz cycle as a internal clock of sorts, but I doubt many current products do anymore.

But the far bigger problem is that while most new products could easily be manufactured to connect to DC power, you're talking about buying a new product to replace the old one. Or significant work to retrofit. In a typical house, your furnace and A/C, major appliances, TVs, lights, garage door opener, sump pump, power tools, kitchen tools, etc etc would all need to be replaced or retrofitted. That's a huge expense. Much easier are the things that have an external transformer (cell phones, laptop, etc) where you'd only have to replace the transformer.  

In the long run, conversion to DC may make sense, but the transition would present huge problems. Each house might need to install a DC-to-AC transformer to run dual for a decade. But even running dual presents a problem because that would mean dual wiring and outlets.

Comment: I am an ex-military military member & have built from parts kits several AR-15 carbine rifles. There is recoil in an AR, but its very little pre single shot & muzzle rise.
Now dumping the magazine with rapid fire, will need you to have a stance & knowledge capable of dealing with the recoil/ muzzle rise.
Now on the parts the M-16 & AR-15 are different internally more than externally.
The bolt carrier, sear, hammer, hammer springs, trigger, trigger springs, safety selector are totally different in both rifles. Bushmaster 2016 Catalog shows a M-16, 3 round burst part set & states that you need to be an FFL or a Form 4 to buy.
Externally, the M-16 carbines have a 14.5" barrel while the AR-15 carbine is 16". NFA law passed around 1936, gave limits on what civilian shotgun & rifle barrel lengths could be & full auto weapons were illegal unless you had the license. So there is a license on certain guns, but not for all.

Comment: I really believe the judge made an error in law based on a plain reading of the law.

The issue is not whether Mr. Olivier would be the Liberal candidate (which is governed by opaque internal party policies and not the elections act), but whether he would be a candidate in the provincial election.

That is, a bribe was offered such that the spurned candidate would not run for another party, or as an independent. 

In fact, the attempted bribe did fail to persuade Mr. Olivier and he did run as an independent. But it's basically guaranteed had he accepted their offer he would not have run.

Therefore, it seems pretty clear that the Liberals offered a bribe to prevent a candidate from running, in contravention of the Elections Act.

Comment: Hello Rich,

I spend a great deal of time in both countries. 

I was 23 when Nixon resigned. The whole process took years and took more TV time than anything in my lifetime except, perhaps, the O J Simpson case.

When TV entered everyones home in the 1960s and early 1970s it acted in a way that established a great deal of prestige for the press. This reached its zenith about 1975 and the press was respected and trusted.

In retrospect, it was at this time that the press had the power to topple an administration and decided to do so.

I think that is no longer true.

In the time since, the press in the US has lost a great deal of  power. I believe that it is now the least trusted institution in the US, well below Trump. They are destroying their last bit of credibility with the public attacking Trump.

Americans no longer have years of patience. They are already beginning to tune out news on Trump. This will come to a conclusion soon or the public will turn on those reporting on it.

Comment: Utter nonsense. Nagasaki and Hiroshima were targeted specifically because they were heavily populated civilian areas. The whole idea was to shock the Japanese imperial command into surrendering by demonstrating the horror of the bomb. It was a cold, calculated and deliberate attack on a civilian population.

The A-bomb wasn't produced to destroy factories, and nobody in their right mind believes that was the intent at Nagasaki and Hiroshima. And even if it were, the fully predictable and inevitable collateral damage would still have made dropping the bombs morally unjustifiable by any reasonable standard, and certainly by the standard of Catholic moral teaching.

I don't judge Truman or the U.S. military. I'm sure they did what they thought was right. But what they did is still objectively horrific, and nobody who rationalizes it has any ground to stand on in criticizing the brutality of others.

Comment: I don't necessarily oppose that, but the devil's in the details. All the numbers you choose have huge real world ramifications.

Unless you increase supply I think there will always be tons of pressure because, as you said, people want to move here—look at SF.

So this could lock in some people who would otherwise be displaced, which is a great thing, but I worry that it would also make it impossible for young, creative people to live here. Because when you lock some people in with rent control, the value of the market rate stuff around it goes up, up, up.

If you want kids in bands and young artists and such, rent control is not going to get you there. Because the people in those spots now will just stay there and get older.

And any kid who grew up here and then went away to school and maybe comes back and gets a really good job making $45,000 would be screwed—they would no qualify for cheap rent so they'd have to live at home or pay big on the open market.

Comment: No degree earned in jumping to conclusions. Good for you on having such expertise, bad on you for slapping a snide label on me from your lofty perch. I may not be an archeologist with a fancy title and published articles, but neither am I stupid. I am aware that 'real' archeology can take grueling hours sifting through muck to tease out small fragments of remains that could prove incredibly valuable. Comment: First, what Ontario is doing is not universal basic income. It is just a glorified unemployment insurance scheme because it claws back fifty cents of every dollar earned by employed recipients. Like unemployment insurance and other welfare programs this claw-back provision is what destroys the incentive to work.  With universal basic income EVERY citizen receives a monthly check.  There is no means testing. Because there is no means testing there are few administrative costs.  Also, because payments are not affected by employment income, everyone still has a strong incentive to work and better their lot in life.  Keep in mind that universal basic income would replace all forms of welfare including unemployment insurance and old age security. The savings to government would be huge. More importantly UBI is a way for lower income workers to maintain dignity and self-respect.  Artists would be free to do their thing.  Crime is likely to fall.  UBI could solve a lot of problems..

Comment: Re rural electrification, I suspect you are well aware that the federal government had to facilitate this because it was initially not deemed sufficiently profitable by private for-profit electricity producers.  I also believe you are correct that the "progressive era" government "response", in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, was to regulate electricity producers or nationalize them to stop price gouging.  But it is less obvious nationalization was chosen in most cases--unless, of course, you are referring to rural electrification and the federal creation of non-profit entities such as the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA).  

But my impression is rural electrification was achieved by creation of many of the larger, and most of the smaller, non-profit customer-owned electric utility co-ops on the mainland, predecessors to the 14-year old Kauai Island Utility Cooperative, and possibly future co-ops or non-profit taxpayer-owned utilities on the Big island and in Maui County-cont

Comment: Excellent article.  Every choice made necessarily precludes other choices foregone.  Language, cultures and traditions are not holy relics to be preserved at all cost.  They all have expiry dates, and propping up those headed for a natural extinction is irrational.  Traditions arise in the context of the culture in which they were developed, and may have little relevance in other cultures (and may, in fact, be disruptive if they run counter to the mores of other cultures).  While it is not necessary to give up old languages, cultures and traditions just because one chooses to live in another culture, bemoaning their loss where they have ceased to be useful is a hollow and counterproductive exercise.

Comment: The "EI fund" was always a myth anyway.

When EI (then UI) was first formed it was supposed to have an actual fund with real money to back it.  Only problem is the benefits paid quickly started exceeding the benefits collected by a vast amount, so the "fund" was bankrupt from very early on.  In the 1980's the "fund", which had no money in it, was abolished.

Under Chretien's Liberals the EI tax (and, to be clear, Canada's EI is very definitely a tax and NOT an employment insurance program) was kept artificially high while benefits were slashed.  The result was that the tax brought in far more revenue than the social programs loosely attached to it, but as with all taxes the money just goes into general revenue.  There was a paper calculation of how much money would be in an "EI Fund" if such a fund were to exist, but there was never so much as a dime in any such fund.

Comment: I get that you mean it's not a tough decision, political spinelessness notwithstanding .. but it'd still be cheaper and more immediately effective to legalize and regulate the production and distribution of recreational drugs.

Distribution outlets staffed by pharmacists (possibly at existing pharmacies) would be less expensive to run than drug-administration centers staffed by nurses and part-time doctors. Overdoses would still go way down due to the predictability of the distributed product. 

And the savings from ending the drug war plus cost-offsetting income from sales at distribution centers would likely be more than enough to pay for these and for universal, highly-available addiction treatment programs.

And for society at large, there's the reduction in property crime and violent turf war crime via a vastly diminished black market...

Comment: This is fantastic!  Great historic bridge, beautiful location.A wonderful historic preservation project but it's ironic it took an Iowa group to see its potential.  Should remind us we have a lot of unrecognized historic jewels around the county.  Lets' hope they can raise the money and all the entangled agencies can work things out together to see this project succeed.  
While the bridge was moved here, it's interesting to note that it was built just 11 years after our own O&C railroad reached Lane County.  Also interesting-- those railroad bridges that  still carry lumber from Coos Bay were built from 1912 to 1916, and one move-in was from  near Drain in 1907.  Hope they are still safe!
This bridge is also a symbol of our early timber industry.  However this statement is a little off- " likely to bring lumber to a Springfield mill from the Marcola hills to the northeast."  No, it probably  carried logs from the Marcola hills to be turned in to lumber in Springfield mills.

Comment: I wouldn't be so quick to assume it's the fault of the French immersion. My kid is in the regular English program, grade 2.  I send him to extra math class because I find what he learns at school is scattershot.  The homework I see does not have practice questions in gradually increasing order of difficulty.  It jumps around, and doesn't reinforce what he's learned.  As a mathematician, I'm regularly aghast at the material he brings home.

In contrast, at the extra-curricular math, each week they have: 
- Drills in addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.  The point of the drills is fluency.
- And "word problems".  They learn 1 new type of word problem about every 3 weeks, and practice about 6 questions a week.  They also periodically review what they've learned this year.  

I've seen a huge change in attitude since he started taking these classes.  In September, he would say "I hate math, it's hard".  Now he says "Of course I'm good at math, it's easy".

Comment: Your editorial is rather short sighted.  Yes, any changes to such a program like Obamacare (ACA) will cause disruption.  However, left to continue as is, Obamacare is doomed to failure. Mandated coverage provisions also affected all health insurance offered in the US, including the Hawaii Prepaid Healthcare Law which provided Hawaii residents the best coverage of any state, and resulted in 50% to 100% increases for Hawaii residents.

Worse of all, Hawaii workers (especially union families) were expected to ante up to pay for Obamacare with a "Cadillac Tax" on overly generous benefits.  Even the Democratic members of Congress cringed so much at this anti-union tax, the implementation has been delayed for 4 years to prevent loss of union supporters.  So in the end, the end of Obamacare is like a vaccine that hurts versus allowing the patient to eventually die

Comment: The system has been in place in Canada for decades for HRSDC to issue a  Labour Market Impact Assessment (LMIA) formerly a Labour Market Opinion (LMO) ) to a specific employer for a specific job for a named TFW unless there is a specific exemption (such as a Mexican or American  professional under NAFTA).  The LMIA certifies that the particular job meets the Canadian standards for wages, working conditions, etc and that there are no Canadian Citizens or Permanent Residents reasonably available to fill the job.
http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/resources/tools/temp/work/opinion/

In certain sectors such as high tech where there is a clear shortage of workers, sector LMIAs  for specific occupations have been issued in the past.

It was a myth perpetrated by some that there was no clearance procedure.  That was an "alternate fact".

Comment: "The big difference between 2017 and 1970 is many more families today -one parent or two parent families - have enough money to send their kids to university."

Don't think so. In 1970 a university degree was not yet considered a sine qua non for a good job and a good life, you could get that with just a high school degree or a trade or in business, and many immigrants came from peasant cultures that did not value education.

Today with educational inflation, a B.A. is the equivalent of a high school or trade diploma then, and immigrants today are educated and value education for their children.

Not to say university should not be free or at least cheaper, but that is not the main factor. You still have segments of society that have not gotten the message and do not raise their kids in view of a university education.

And the greater issue imo is that there will always be a large segment that is just not university material, Germany for example recognizes that and offers alternatives.

The pesticide testing is a lot more expensive and it's utility is more shady.  It's never been clear that pesticides are in use or have ever caused any health problems.  The main pesticide they discovered in Colorado (Eagle 20) is a common mold inhibitor sprayed on all kinds of produce, but the rub is that it is approved to be eaten, not smoked due to the metabolic pathway.

Comment: Up until billions of humans started to modify the content of the earth’s atmosphere, atmospheric temperatures were responding to Milankovitch forcing. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milankovitch_cycles 

Milankovitch forcing produced a maximum rebound in temperatures some 7,000 (+/-) years ago followed by cooling which culminated in “The Little Ice Age” some 200 to 300 years ago. (See the Daily Isolation graph at the above Wikipedia link.)

Note that we would have stayed at this cooler level for the next 5,000+ years – except for human intervention.

Some 150+ years ago John Tyndall discovered that carbon dioxide absorbs long wavelength (heat) radiation. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:TyndallsSetupForMeasuringRadiantHeatAbsorptionByGases_annotated.jpg The earth is warming because carbon dioxide retards the earth’s ability to get rid of excess heat.

How long will it take Global Warming deniers to understand the results of this discovery?

Comment: "It opened up a new sea lane for China," the news agency said. "From Shanghai to New York, the traditional route that passes through the Panama Canal is 10,500 nautical miles, while the route that passes through the Northwest Passage is 8,600 nautical miles, which saves 7 days of time."


Yeah, sure it does, on paper.
In reality, ships transiting the Northwest Passage don't just charge through at top cruising speed (even at the height of summer). There are many uncharted underwater hazards and constantly shifting summer ice, that combined, require ships to reduce speed and change course many times throughout the transit. Those '7 days' of possible saved time evaporate quickly before most ships are through the Passage.

We don't have much to be concerned about , few ships will be using the Northwest Passage as a regular cargo route, anytime soon !
